bioghist.p: According to a financial report in the collection, the Soabar Company was formed in 1912 as H. G. Davis Manufacturing Co. The company was formed for the purpose of "manufacturing, selling, and leasing machinery, tags, tickets, and labels." The company was originally located on Frankford Avenue. Subsequent locations were also in the Frankford area. In 1920 the stockholders changed the name to Soabar Co. This name is apparently based upon the invention of the sew-ticketing machine. The company did a great deal of business with clothing retailers, including Strawbridge & Clothier , John Wanamaker, Gimbels, and Montgomery Ward & Co.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes records for the Soabar Company and several subsidiary companies that eventually merged into Soabar, namely: Joseph J. Stone & Co. (1939-1965), Dixie Tag & Envelope Company (1940s-1950s), Rotag Manufacturing Corporation (1950s), and Robinson Tag & Label Co. (1953-1962). There are also records for the Soabar GmbH (1960s-1976), a German subsidiary. The collection includes minutes of executive committees and boards of directors, charters and bylaws,financial records, patents, documentation of the Company's 1968 merger with Avery, and records on product liability litigation. There is also extensive photographic documentation of staff members, board of directors members, products, company events, and factory buildings, as well as promotional materials, label samples, brochures for ticketing machines, company newsletters, and a scrapbook.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
